results.title: Hoppity pop
results.brief_description: An animated film in which coloured shapes dance in time to old-fashioned calling music. The film was made without a camera, by drawing directly upon the film with ordinary pen and ink. Simple, swift moving forms dance about the screen, carrying out the mood of the music as the humorous aspect of the old time circus calliope - missing stops and a tendency to go out of tune - are all included on the soundtrack. No commentary.

results.title: Hoppin' mad [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: David McKay Design and David McKay
results.brief_description: Cold Chisel’s “Cheap wine” sing along by two travelling German tourists is rudely interrupted when their car hits a kangaroo. Not wanting to waste a photo opportunity with one of Australia’s most famous native animals, Rainer and Dirk take time out to pose with “Skippy”, with surprising results. In German with English subtitles.

results.title: Hopper's Silence
results.brief_description: An extremely informative and entertaining account of American realist painter Edward Hopper. We see archival as well as contemporary interviews with Hopper as he discusses his paintings and his view of American society.

results.title: Hopi Indians: arts and crafts
results.brief_description: Looks at the arts and crafts of the Hopi Indians focusing on weaving, silversmithing, basket making and pottery. Records the skill and patience required in these rapidly disappearing arts.
results.description: Looks at the arts and crafts of the Hopi Indians focusing on weaving, silversmithing, basket making and pottery. Records the skill and patience required in these rapidly disappearing arts.

results.title: Hope Street (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: East West Films and Ivan Hexter
results.brief_description: Homelessness is a major dilemma for many young Australians. Through the experiences of several young characters living in a refuge, caravan park and squat, Hope Street explores the reasons for their homelessness, the impact it has on their lives and the ways in which these young people endeavour to resolve their predicaments.

results.title: Hope is not a method. - Rev. ed.
results.brief_description: Cites and describes seven contraceptive methods with anatomiclaly explicit diagrams. States the advantages and disadvantages of withdrawal, rhythm, spermicidal chemicals, the condom, the diaphragm, the pill, the IUD and sterilization. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Hope is not a method
results.brief_description: The purpose of this film is to convey and illustrate the various methods of birth control. Seven types of contraception, in addition to vasectomy and tubal ligation are illustrated by means of animation and live action.

results.title: Hope for the handicapped
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board and State Film Centre of Victoria
results.brief_description: This film documents what was, for its time, a revolutionary breakthrough in occupational therapy - the pursuit of simple industrial vocation in sheltered workshops. A range of Victorian sheltered workshops are surveyed, and the filmmakers are keen to promote the greater satisfaction afforded their subjects by work which is both financially rewarding and socially useful.

results.title: Hope and glory
results.brief_description: John Boorman recreates the London and England of his childhood, when he was a young boy living through the excitement of the Blitz, whilst the adults around him were dealing with the horror of war as best they could. In contrast to the adult’s fears, for the children the war also brings adventure and excitement, and much of the film’s comedy comes from the differing perspective’s between the “grown-ups” and the “kiddies”. The recreation of war-time London is visually spot-on. Boorman wrote the screenplay. The film stars Sarah Miles.
